loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy U. is 27 years old and she is a farmer who rents a small piece of land to grow crops for supporting her family. Her husband, Mr. Saven Yum, is a barber. They live in Svay Mean Leak village in Kandal province. This family has a problem because their house is too old to live in. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Chanthy U. decided to ask for a loan to repair the house. She is the mother of two children who are too small to work or study. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M. is from the village of Malaubang Ozamiz city. She is 50 years old. Myrna is widowed and has 3 school-aged children.

To make a living, Myrna sells seafood products including fish and shrimp to the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Myrna joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting her first loan from GDMPC, for 10000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is from the village of Malaubang Ozamiz City. She is 46 years old. Susan is married and has 8 adult-aged children.

To make a living, Susan sells clothing and shoe products to the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Susan joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan is requesting her first loan from GDMPC, for 10000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Rai

texts.en: Mrs. Rai R. is 48 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Thorn Bun, live in Preak Doung village in Kandal province. They are farmers who own 2.5-hectares of land for cultivating rice to support their family. They have some problems with the rice field because it has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects, but they don't have enough money to correct these problems. In order to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Rai R. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide for the farm. She has seven children, five of whom are farmers, while the others are attending the local public school. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Merced

texts.en:
Merced A. is from the village of Poblacon, Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Merced is single and has 3 school-aged children.

To make a living, Merced prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals and she also sells soft drinks and some food for snacks. Merced has been engaged in her business for one year and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Merced joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merced successfully repaid a previous loan of 1500 PHP from GDMPC. Merced is requesting her fourth loan, for 2000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

Merced plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Reth

texts.en: Mrs. Reth K. is 63 years old. She is a mother of two children, who are employed in a garment factory. She and her husband, Mr. Nguon Hieng Se (pictured left), live in Kandal Kaoh Touch village in Kandal province. They are farmers who own 1.5-hectares of land that they cultivate in order to support their family. However hard Mrs. Reth K. and her husband work on their farm, they do not earn sufficient income because the amount of land they own is too small. Therefore, in order to improve their crop yield, Mrs. Reth K. decided to apply for a loan to buy more land for growing vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more land to grow vegetables

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon M. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 26 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sharon owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sharon has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2010, Sharon joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 40 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports the home. Grace owns a grocery store where she sells groceries such as milk, loaves of bread and tomato paste. She is requesting a loan of 120,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and own a supermarket. Grace thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 38 years old, married, and has one child. She owns a stall where she sells household items such as cooking pots. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. Helen is very determined to expand her business, and has a good relationship with Kiva partner, LAPO. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more household items to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

About LAPO
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more household items to sell

loans.name: On

texts.en: Mrs. On T. is a villager from Pouthi Reamea village in Kandal province. She is 32 years old and the mother of three children, all of whom are enrolled in the local public school. She and her husband, Mr. Kreng Kea (pictured right), are fruit sellers. However hard they work in their business, they still do not earn sufficient income because they have little capital to support the business. Therefore, in order to improve their family's living conditions, Mrs. On T. decided to ask for a loan to buy more mangoes for resale.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes for resale

loans.name: Tynymkan's Group

texts.en:
In general, women are considered to be strong and responsible, and their attitude to life is stable, even in difficulties. Here is a story about one woman, which is an example of bravery and self-confidence.
After her marriage, Tynymkan M. never dreamed she would suffer. As the eldest child in her family, she was responsible – and that is why she did not think much about marriage. However, kidnapping is common in the country; Tynymkan was kidnapped, but she still thought about her family and her brothers and sisters. Unless her siblings married, she took care of them. She also decided to take care of herself because she was getting older.
Finally, Tynymkan gave birth, little knowing that her happiness would not last much longer. Her husband died the same year from a heart attack. At that moment, it seemed her life was totally destroyed. However, her child motivated her to move on. Her son became an adult and graduated from university. But life is very cruel, and on the way home, he fought with a group of scum who mutilated him forever. He is now 40 years old and an invalid.
The situation was unimaginable. However, Tynymkan took a loan of 15,000 KGS and bought three sheep for fattening and reselling. Now her life is not so bad, and she is requesting another loan to increase her number of cattle in order to sell them and help her child.

Aynagul B. is 39 and married. She has five children, and her husband works as a welder for a company. Her elder daughter works in a café as a waitress while the rest are still at home. Five years ago, they bought some cattle with her husband's salary and began their business. They are planning to increase their number of cattle so that they can educate their children. They want to take a loan in order to buy fodder.

Aynur J. is 39, a widow, and has two children who both attend the local school. She is planning to apply for a job and marry successfully. She is requesting a loan for dental treatment.

Aygul J. is 38, married, and has five children. Her husband works as a driver in a company. She wants a loan to buy building materials in order finish their house.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy more cattle for resale

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Mrs. Ou H. is 37 years old and lives in Preak Reussei village in Kandal province. She is a widow who has three children, two of whom are enrolled in a local public school while the other is too young to work or study.
In her rice field, Mrs. Ou H. has some problems because her farm is far from the irrigation system and she does not have money to support it. Therefore, in order to improve her rice production, she decided to ask for a loan to dig a well. With the rest of her loan, she would like to buy fertilizer, fuel and pesticide.

loans.use: To dig a well, and buy fuel, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Elita

texts.en:
Elita L. is from the village of Rizal Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Elita is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Elita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling fruits and vegetables in the market. Elita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elita is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 49 years old, married, and has seven children, the youngest of whom is 12 years old. Rose is a hardworking woman and a faithful client of Kiva partner, LAPO. Rose is a farmer who plants various crops on her farm. She is always happy during harvest when she sells her harvested crops to sellers.
Rose hopes to expand her farm and is therefore requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more farming tools, such as a cutlass and hoes. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more farming tools

loans.name: Han

texts.en:
Mr. Han N. is 36 years old and a villager in Preak Reussei village in Kandal province. He is a father of five children who are all enrolled in a local public school. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Yoeun Pen (pictured right), is a string seller.
In his rice field, Mr. Han N. has some problems because his field is far from the irrigation system, and he does not have money to support it. Therefore, in order to improve his rice production, Mr. Han N. decided to ask for a loan to dig a well. With the rest of the loan, he would like to hire someone to even out the land.

loans.use: To dig a well

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita O. is from Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 61 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mercedita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2008, Mercedita joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her fourth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kamau

texts.en:
Mr. Kamau is a 55-year-old man who has been operating a car wash business for twenty years in which he employs one person. Previously, he was involved in bicycle and motorcycle repair. He also earns extra income from dairy farming.

Mr. Kamau appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping him become financially independent. He previously took a loan of Kes 60,000 and he now plans to take a loan of Kes 65,000 so as to purchase a car wash machine.

Mr. Kamau hopes to make a big investment in his business in the future. He hopes that, if he retires, he will let his sons inherit his business. He describes himself as ambitious and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase a car wash machine

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa F. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old. Theresa is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Theresa owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Theresa has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Theresa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Theresa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Theresa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Helenita

texts.en:
Helenita T. is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in various business activities: she raises pigs, runs a general store,  has a passenger tricycle, and sells food. She lives in Bucrus Daku Brgy Ayungon La Carlota, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their two children, who are 19 and 16 years old; both children currently go to school.

Helenita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig fattening, general store, tricyle and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,500.

Helenita is now borrowing PHP 15,000 for her pig fattening and general store businesses. This will be her 14th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Helenita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Delphine

texts.fr: V. Delphine est née en 1956 et vit depuis 20 ans à Agla, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BANKOLE Léon un retraité du service des impôts, Delphine est mère de six enfants tous scolarisés, dont cinq sont à sa charge. Delphine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Delphine n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a près de 30 ans que Delphine vend divers produits (sucre, savons, gâteaux d'arachides, conserves de tomate et de sardine, pâtes alimentaires, laits etc.). Delphine fabrique et vend également du savon local (fait à base de soda et d'huile). Delphine  effectue ses achats à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Adja, dans le Mono. Delphine  vend ses produits à son domicile et quelques fois à Dantokpa. Delphine  est une cliente fidèle de ALIDé car ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Dans l'espoir d'épargner plus d'argent pour se construire une maison, Delphine    sollicite un troisième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Delphine V. was born in 1956 and has been living for the past 20 years in the Agla neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Léon BANKOLE, a retired tax agent, she is the mother of six children, all having had schooling, and of which five are still under her care. She lives with her husband and children, and she shares family expenses with her husband. Delphine has only attended primary school. For 30 years Delphine has been selling various products (sugar, soap, peanut cakes, canned tomatoes, sardines, pasta, milk, etc.). She also retails locally made soap (made from caustic soda and oil). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and from Adja, in the Mono region. She sells her products from her home and sometimes in Dantokpa. Delphine is a faithful client of ALIDé and has previously been granted two loans, both duly repaid. She is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé, with the hope of putting more money into savings and eventually building a house.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy caustic soda to make soap, and various food products (pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, etc.)

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace W. N. is 37 years old, single and has one child who is five years old. Grace's business is located at Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. Grace has been selling fruit, such as mangoes, oranges, passion fruits, etc., for the past five years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and her major challenge is harassment by the local government. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Grace is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes to expand her business. She hopes to have another business that is totally different from what she currently does. She also hopes to educate her child to university level, buy a plot of land, and build a house for her family. She is hardworking, God fearing and friendly.

loans.use: To expand her food vending business by buying sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en:
Marianita C. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and by selling vegetables. She lives in Bucrus Daku La Carlota City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their child, who is 18 years old and currently goes to school.

Marianita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her general store and vegetable vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000.

Marianita is now borrowing PHP 29,000 so that she can buy additional products for the general store, as well as vegetables to sell. This will be her 18th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marianita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her general store and vegetable vending businesses

loans.name: Raymunda

texts.en:
Raymunda P. is a married woman who supports her family through her dressmaking and tailoring business. She lives in Bongalanon, Basay, Negros Oriental with her husband Jose. He is 58 years old and works as a fisherman. They have eight children, some of whom are working and some are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her dressmaking/tailoring business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $68.

Raymunda is now borrowing 10,000 PHP so that she can buy additional clothes and materials for tailoring. This will be her 7th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 8,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Raymunda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional clothes and materials for tailoring

loans.name: Maximeno, Sr.

texts.en:
Maximeno F. is from the village of Lupagan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 70 years old, is married, and has six adult children.

Maximeno owns and operates a business providing party services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over forty years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Maximeno joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in renovating his business.

Maximeno is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP which will again be used to invest in renovating his business. This loan will be his 5th PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a single man who has an electronics shop where he deals in mobile phones and employs two people. He also earns extra income from his pharmacy.

Since Simon joined Faulu Kenya, his standard of living has improved because of increased stock in his business. He has requested Kes 50,000 to increase his stock and to start a poultry keeping business. He hopes to create employment for many jobless youth.

Simon dreams of expanding his business and diversifying his products in the future. He describes himself as a dedicated entrepreneur with a passion.

loans.use: To add to his stock of mobile phones and to start a poultry business

loans.name: Mrs. Savoen Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has seventeen people whom all live in Preak Traeng village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Savoen S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Savoen S. is a fabric middleman and her husband, Mr. Ly M., is a driver who is not able to earn enough salary to support his family. In order to improve the family’s living conditions, Mrs. Savoen S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fabric to re-sell.

Mrs. Savoen S. is the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local public school while the other one is too young to work or study.

Mrs Chab P., who is a group guarantor is also present in the photo with the village bank loan members.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to re-sell

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira M. is a lucky and successful woman.   She was born into a farmer's family.   As a child, there were some days when she was starving.  Now, at 42, she has a happy family, with three boys and a really smart husband.   She works as an accountant in a petrol company. Her salary per month is 5.000 KGS ($110). Her husband works as a driver at the same company. He also drives passengers when he is free. So his total income is 4.000 – 5.000 KGS ($90- $110). They have bought a car,  a Volkswagen Passat. They are planning to buy a new house and pay the tuition of their second son when goes to university. They decided to get a loan to pay for their  first son’s tuition. 

Gulnara S. is 49 and married . She is already a grandmother. She has six children; the oldest two boys and daughter are married and live separately. The youngest one works in the capital. Her husband is a private business owner who resells machinery.  In the future, they plan to buy a house for their son.   Their income is 10.000 KGS ($224). They are seeking a loan to increase turnover.  

Bahtiyar R. is 23. He works at the petrol station as a security guard and earns 6.000 KGS ($133). With the help of his parents he has bought cattle for 50.000 KGS ($1117).  Now he wants to get a loan to buy barley for 6.000 KGS ($133), wheat for 4.000 KGS ($90), solar oil for 4.000 KGS ($90) in order to work on the field,  He will use the rest of the loan to buy small cattle.

Dildesh B. is 42 and married. She is a housewife and has two children, who both attend school. Her husband works in the local petrol station. They are seeking a loan to buy small cattle.

Kenjekan B. is is 44 and married.  She has four children; two daughters who are married and two sons who attend school. She works at a local poultry farm as a sorter and has a monthly salary of 6.000 ($130). Her husband provides taxi service. The family owns a pavilion, where they sell detergent and perfumery materials.  Their monthly gross revenue is 100.000 KGS ($2,200). They are engaged in cattle raising as well and want to apply for a loan to buy cattle and perfumery materials.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay tuition for education

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a businesswoman who sells fresh tomatoes in an open area in Benin City, Edo State. Fresh tomatoes are used to prepare mouth-watering Nigerian cooked foods. She has been in this business for a long time. As a hardworking woman, she sells for long hours to support her home.

Eunice is 45 years old and married with four children, her youngest being 12 years old. Her children are excelling in school.

Eunice hopes for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more fresh tomatoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet R. is from the village of Pontod, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Juliet owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Mrs. Malis Phai Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has fourteen people who all live in Preak Traeng village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Malis P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Malis P. is a fish breeder and her husband, Mr. Thy Orem, is a fisherman. This family has a problem because their fish are too small to sell, but they did not have enough money to support them. Thus, in order to improve their family’s living conditions, Mrs. Malis P. decided to ask for a loan to buy fish food for her fish.

Mrs. Malis P. is the mother of a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fish food for her fish

loans.name: Abies

texts.en:
Abies is 34 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a land surveyor and he also supports the home.

Abies is a friendly and hardworking woman. She has a grocery store where she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future.

Abies hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a 38-year-old married man with three children of whom two attend school. He has been running a butcher for two years, employing two people to assist him. He was previously working in a hotel (restaurant).

Through Faulu Kenya, George started saving his money and he plans to take his first loan of Kes 20,000. He wants to use this loan to buy a meat mincer and grill.

George hopes to build his own home in Nairobi in the future. He sees himself opening another butcher shop within Nairobi in the future. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy a meat mincer and grill

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel M. M. is twenty four years old, married, and has one six-month-old child. His business is located at Kimbo in Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. 

He provides transportation to the local people. He has been in this business for the last two years. He says that this business is profitable but his major challenge is the high cost of maintenance. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 20,000 KES to buy a modern motorbike to be able to do his business well. He wants to be the best in terms of customer care to catch a larger market share.

loans.use: Motor bike.

loans.name: Tom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Tom S. is a tailor in her village and her husband, Mr. Sat Hai, is a real estate broker. This family has a problem because their sewing machine is too old to use, but they do not have enough money to buy a new one. Thus, in order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Tom S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new sewing machine to use instead of the old one. She is the mother of two children who are attending the local public school.

This group consists of five people who all live in Prachum Angk village in Kandal province. Mrs. Tom S. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. They will use their loan for different purposes.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Phina

texts.en: Phina sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-to-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She hopes to own a maternity home in the future. Phina is married to a businessman and they have a lovely 4 years old child. Phina is 32 years old and she hopes to lift her business and her family above poverty. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta T. is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 65 years old. Loreta is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Loreta owns & operates a general store. Loreta is just starting this business.

In 2009, Loreta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Loreta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Loreta is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Loreta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Shayrbubu's Group

texts.en:
Balykchy is one of the towns of Kyrgyzstan where apricots grown well and which is famous not only for fish and historical background, but also for its hardworking, self-confident citizens. Kyrgyz men cannot usually show their stability in difficulties, but women are something magical. Shayrbubu B., a leader of this group, is not an exception. After the death of her husband from heart attack, leaving her with two children, she had not been destroyed. Quite the contrary, she became stronger because she understood that from that moment everything she would do was just for the benefit of her children. That moment, she was about thirty and her daughter was five and son was four years old, cute ones. With money she had saved, she bought a cow. By fattening and selling milk of the cow, she could have daily bread. Day by day, everything became better. Now she is a sixty year old, widowed woman who has already up brought two children. Her daughter is thirty-three and her son is thirty-five. They have both graduated from university and become their mother’s supporters and defenders. She breeds small cattle and resells them. Her revenue is 700 KGZ (15$) per month, which is terrible. They have hopes to buy apricot seedlings and have a harvest after 2-3 years. She wants to get a loan to make her dreams come true. 

Raysa K. is divorced and has a daughter at the age of twenty-eight who is already married and a housewife. Now she sells cosmetics of “Faberlic” and her total revenue is 2,500 KGZ (55$) per month. She wants to get 8,000 KGZ (180$) to buy cosmetics in order to sell them in spring because it is implemented well on that season.

Ayjamal S. is married woman and has a daughter who attends kindergarten. They want to get a loan of 15,000 KGZ (335$) to buy furniture.

Tatyana K. is a married woman who has a daughter. Her daughter is already married and lives separately. Her husband works as an electrician in a company. They are dreaming about a new flat and that’s why they are going to take a loan of 20,000 KGZ (445$) to make their dreams come true.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy apricot seedlings and have harvest after 2-3 years

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita O. is from the village of Santiago, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old. Mercedita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Mercedita owns & operates a business buying and selling bananas in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Mercedita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is a 43-year-old married man with four children in school. He sells fishing flies and has been in the business for six years and employs four people. He also earns extra income from farming. He requested for a loan of KES 40,000 to buy materials for manufacturing fishing flies, to meet his customer’s demands. He hopes to buy a plot and build rental houses and to educate his children to higher levels of education. He dreams of becoming economically independent and of have a big business. He describes himself as humble and hardworking.

loans.use: Purchase of 'fishing flies' raw materials.

loans.name: Anne Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1974, G. Anne Marie est mariée à GOUDEGNON Pierre un peintre. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille réside depuis une dizaine d’année au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Anne Marie vend de l'huile d'arachide et de palme et également de "sodabi" (boisson alcoolisée locale) de façon ambulante. Anne Marie vend également des condiments et du charbon de bois à son domicile, ce qui lui, permet d'avoir plusieurs sources de revenu. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et au marché de Houègbo dans le département de l'Atlantique, que Anne Marie s'approvisionne. Anne Marie exerce cette activité depuis 20 ans, et rembourse bien les crédits qu'elle prend à ALIDé. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité pour mieux faire face à la demande des clients, Anne Marie sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1974, Anne Marie G. is married to Pierre GOUDEGNON, a painter. The couple has three children, all attending school. For the past ten years the family has been living in the Fidjrossé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple share family expenses. To meet her needs, Anne Marie is an itinerant vendor selling peanut and palm-nut oil, and also “sodabi” (a local alocoholic beverage). She also sells culinary condiments and charcoal from her home, which provides her with several sources of income. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and from the Houègbo market in the Department of the Atlantic. Anne Marie has been in this line of business for the past 20 years, and has fully reimbursed previous loans granted from ALIDé. To increase her working capital, reinforce her activity and better respond to customer demand, Anne Marie is now requesting another laon from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 50-liter jerrycans of palm-nut oil, peanut oil, and sodabi

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica W. M. is forty years old, married, and has two children aged twenty and ten. Her husband is a driver and they hope to provide their children with a quality education. They also hope to build a beautiful house to live in some day. Monica's business is located at Makongeni, a busy market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

She has been selling cereals such as rice for five years to shopkeepers and individuals. She says that this business is profitable and her major challenge is financial constraints. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Monica is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more cereals to expand her business. She hopes to grow her business and supply her cereals to different parts of the country in the future. She is very patient, cheerful and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more cereals to sell

loans.name: Gwenotwom B Anena Kevin Group

texts.en: A. Kevin is a hardworking business woman, age 30. She is blessed with four children, of whom three are going to school. She owns a restaurant and she has been operating it for over five months. She is using this loan to purchase food (rice, millet flour, maize flour, sauce, and so forth) for her restaurant business. Her dream is to improve her welfare.

loans.use: To purchase food supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline D. is from the village of Capundag, in Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental.  She is 33 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. In 2006, Evangeline joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 45,000 PHP from PMPC.  She is now requesting a new loan of 36,000 PHP which will be used to redeem her coconut plantation. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Evangeline from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to redeem her coconut plantation

loans.name: Good News

texts.en: Good News is a hard-working 29 year-old woman.  She is married with one child, and lives in Benin with her family. Good News is a fashion designer who also sells tailoring materials. She makes lovely Nigerian designs for her customers. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda P. is from the village of Maac, in Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Brenda owns & operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Brenda has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Brenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan Brenda has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Alrie Quinimon Group

texts.en:
Alrie Q. is from the village of Pan-ay Diot, in Tudela, Misamis Occidental Province. She is 32 years old. Alrie is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Alrie is single. To make a living, she owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling dried goods in the local community. Alrie is just starting this business.

In 2010, Alrie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan Alrie has taken from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vitalish

texts.en: Vitalish is 40 years old and married with six children.  He has been running an electronics repair shop in the Kibera slums for 20 years and has employed one person.  He earns extra income from dressmaking.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to stock his business with the required spare parts. This improved his standard of living.  He has requested a loan of KES 40,000 to buy spare parts such as motherboards,  lenses and solder.   He hopes to open a TV shop.  He expects to increase his income from KES 20,000 to KES 100,000 per month and expand his clientele from 80 to 4000 clients in the future.  He describes himself as hardworking and effective in his job.  He esteems his customers and serves them well.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts

loans.name: Osarentin

texts.en: Osarentin renders computer and photostating services to her customers. She has been in this business for five years. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more stationery to improve her computer services. She is 30 years old and married without children. She hopes to have children someday. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to improve her computer services

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: Née en 1963 à Bohicon dans le département du Zou, A. Julienne est mariée à AGBANNON Faustin, un cuisinier. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés. Il y a 11 ans que la famille s'est installée à Fidjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne assure avec son mari les différentes charges familiales. Julienne n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses charges, Julienne  vend des sachets et des gâteaux (fabriqués avec le maïs) de façon ambulante. Julienne vend également et de façon secondaire, de l'akassa (aliment local fait à base de maïs) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Julienne fait ses provisions. Julienne mène cette activité depuis une vingtaine d'année et a déjà bénéficié de créditss auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Julienne sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de satisfaire la demande croissante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Bohicon in the Department of Zou, Julienne A. is married to Faustin AGBANNON, a cook. The couple has five children, all having had schooling. The family settled 11 years ago in the Fidjrossé Kpota neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Julienne manages with her husband the family expenses. She has not attended school. To meet her financial obligations, Julienne is an itinerant vendor selling plastic bags and corn-mush cakes. As a side business, she also sells akassa (a local corn-based food preparation) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Julienne has been in this line of business for 20 years and has already been granted credit loans from ALIDé, which she has repaid in full. She is now requesting another loan to increase her stock supply and satisfy the increasing customer demand for her offerings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy plastic bags in bulk and corn for the preparation of corn-cakes and akassa

loans.name: Gwenotwom B Ayaa Nighty Group

texts.en: A. Nighty is a thirty-eight year-old business woman. She is married with eight children, of whom six are going to school; she also has four dependents. She sells flour, silver fish, and other products. She has been in her business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase tomatoes, flour, and other products to sell. She is an encouraging and active business woman whose future hopes are to educate her children and purchase a grinding machine.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes, flour, and other products to sell

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza S. is from the village of Lawigan, in Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Riza is widowed and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, she owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Riza has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Riza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Riza is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This loan will be the 1st loan Riza has taken from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose owns a grocery store where she sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is a hard working woman who loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Rose loves her business and family so much that she is determined to lift them out of poverty. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She is 53 years old and married to a commercial driver. Her husband also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John M. W. is twenty three years old, married, and does not have children yet. His business is located at Kiganjo, a busy market in Thika town in the Kimuchu area of Kenya. 

He provides transport to the local people. He has been in this business for the last year. He says that it's a good business venture, but due to many breakdowns of his motorcycle he wants to start another business.

That is why John is using his 20,000 KES to start up an electronics shop to better his income. In the future he hopes to purchase a house for his family. He is very hardworking, patient and fun loving.

loans.use: To start an electronics business.

loans.name: Mrs. Phin Dim Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan involves twenty-two people, all of whom live in Prachum Angk village, in Kandal province. All the group members are shown in the picture, but some of them are blocked.

Mrs. Phin D. is her village bank president; she has been selected by all the members, who will use their loans for different purposes. She is a beautician in her village, while her husband, Mr. Thea S., is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to support his family. Phin D. is a mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school. This family has a problem because they do not have enough beauty supplies for Phin D.’s business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy some beauty supplies.

loans.use: to buy beauty supplies

loans.name: Janylbubu's Group

texts.en: The coldest place in Kyrgyzstan is Naryn. In the period of the Soviet Union, Naryn was the capital, because everything was imported firstly to Naryn. Although Naryn is the coldest place, people there are very kind. Their hospitality is amazing. In spite of crisis, even now, they may cut a sheep for one guest. Whole families can be fed for about a month by one sheep, but citizens of Naryn may cut it for one person in order to show that he is welcome. Janylbubu K. is just like this. She is a kind, open-minded person. Because she gives something, God is giving her. God already gave her health; besides that, He gave her a really hardworking husband and brilliant son. She adores them because they are really good friends and her best supporters. Her husband is on pension but still works at home as a joiner and makes fascinating items. A simple piece of wood can turn out to be a beautiful souvenir. It is his hobby but, at same time, it provides an opportunity to earn their daily bread. They bought a joiner bench and began their business. Later on, with the money they earned (about 5,000 soms or $112), they bought cattle. Now their revenue is 4,000 soms ($90). They are planning to build a house and marry off their son. They decided to take out a loan to buy raw materials. Sabira O. is a 50-year-old married woman. She has two children: a daughter and a son. Her daughter is a student and her son also attends school. Her husband is a taxi driver. They want to take out a loan to buy two tonnes of coal. With the rest of the money, they will buy sheep. Cholpon O. is a 54-year-old married woman. Her two children attend the local school and her husband works as an electrician at the school. They want to take out a loan to buy coal. Their plan is to buy a house for their son. Aynagul M. is a 57-year-old married woman. She has five children: four of them live separately and her youngest daughter is a student. Her husband is a joiner who makes frames and doors. Their revenue is 3,000 soms ($67). They want to buy a horse – that’s why they need a loan. Suusar B. is a 50-year-old married woman. She has two sons. The older one is 25; he is a tractor driver and helps his father. The younger one is a student. They are planning to build a house for their sons and increase the number of their cattle. They want to take out a loan to buy a cow and, with the rest, they are planning to buy coal. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to further your support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for wooden souvenir production

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope is an Agbor man by tribe but he lives and works in Benin City. He is a hard working man. He is 29 years old and single without children.

He renders rental services in his community. He rents chairs, tables and canopies to people in his community.  He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is also responsible for taking care of his parents.

He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more tables and chairs. He duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chairs and tables

loans.name: Gwenotwom B Achomo Christine Group

texts.en:
Christine A. is thirty years old, a single lady with two children who are in school. She owns a grocery business and she has been dealing in this business for over five years.

She is using the loan to purchase tomatoes for sale. At least the loan is increasing her capital as well as the stock of her business. She is an active business woman whose dream is to obtain poultry.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 57 year old father of three children.  He has seen two of his children through school and his last born is in college.   He was formerly employed in a construction firm before he ventured in a metal fabrication business.

His business has been running for ten years and he employs three people.  He also earns extra income from farming.  He feels that Faulu Kenya is a very wonderful MFI and even wished that he would have joined a long time ago as he claims that he would have achieved his dreams.

He requests Kes.50,000  to buy metal to add to his stock.  He hopes to own a factory which deals with metal fabrication in the future.

loans.use: Add stock of metal for welding business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary W. is forty eight years old, married, and has four children between the ages of twenty and twenty-six. Her business is located at Gachororo in Thika, Kenya. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

Mary has been selling dresses, trousers, and so on for the last four years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is the high cost of materials. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 40,000 KES to restock her business to grow it and be able to serve more people.

loans.use: To restock clothing to sell

loans.name: Wendelyn

texts.en:
Wendelyn A. is from the city of Santiago in Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Wendelyn is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Wendelyn makes and sells snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Wendelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Wendelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wendelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients to make the food that she sells. Wendelyn is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Wendelyn's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Gomez Group

texts.en:
Edelyn G. is from the village of San Vicente. She is 28 years old. Edelyn is the leader of a 2-member loan group sponsored by PMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Edelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Edelyn runs a "motorcycle for hire" transportation service for local community members. Edelyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Edelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for LTO Registration renewal. Edelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to repair the motorcycle that she uses in the business. This will be Edelyn's fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her motorcycle

loans.name: Dulamdorj

texts.en:
Dulamdorj is 59 years old. She lives with her husband and son in the Chingeltei District of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  She and her family live in a "ger," a yurt or Mongolian nomadic tent. They used to rent a place to live, but with the profits from their business, they bought their own tent, and the whole family now lives in it. Dulamdorj's husband and son run a taxi service using their own car. 

Dulamdorj sells traditional Mongolian clothing at her own counter in the Narantuul Market, one of the biggest markets in Mongolia. She started her business in 1990. Originally, she sewed traditional Mongolian clothing to supply to the  Narantuul Market's sales people. At that time, her total working capital was 500,000 tugrugs (~ $351 USD), and average monthly sales revenue was 1,000,000 tugrugs (~ $700 USD).  Now she has expanded her business, and her total working capital is 2,100,000 tugrugs (~ $1477 USD) and average monthly sales revenue is 2,000,000 – 2,500,000 tugrugs (~ $1565 USD).  

She has a great business mind and says “I would like to expand my business and workplace.” She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~ $2100 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of material to prepare for the Mongolian Lunar New Year celebration. During this holiday, customer demand  is very high.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of material to make traditional Mongolian clothes to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Selling of lubricants is a business that has benefited Eunice's life. She is 36 years old and married, and she has two children. Her eldest child is 6 years old. She sells lubricants, such as engine oil, at retail prices. She has been in this business for seven years. She hopes to expand her business. 

Eunice is hoping for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more lubricants to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more lubricants to sell

loans.name: Gwenotwom C Aryemo Nathaline Group

texts.en:
Nathaline A. is forty years old. She is single and she has four children in school and two dependents. She owns a grocery store where she sells food, such as cassava, beans, ground nuts, and simsim (sesame seeds). She has been in her business for over four years. 

She is using her loan to purchase groceries to sell. She is an active and courageous woman. She hopes to expand her business by purchasing produce.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Norita

texts.en:
Norita is 56 years old and married with three children: two daughters and one son.   She lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.  Her husband Dante works in the construction business.  To supply additional income for her family, Norita is starting a business selling fried fish.

Norita would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory to launch her business including cardboard boxes as well as fish.  As a new member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Norita is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. 
  
With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her new business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.  Her long-term dreams are to continue supporting her children and grandchildren as well as building a stronger home that can withstand flooding common in her province.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase inventory to launch her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a cassava flour mill

loans.name: Leoncie

texts.en:
Leoncie is 42 years old, she is married, and she has one child 12 years old. Leoncie lives in the Ngoma, a region of Rwamagana situated in the Eastern Province of Rwanda. Here, Leoncie has a business sewing various models of clothes. She has been in this business for about twenty-five years and she starts sewing early in the morning hours until late in the evening.

Leoncie needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can expand her business through adding more sewing machines. With these additional sewing machines, Leoncie hopes to sew different styles of clothes which in turn will attract more customers.

With this loan, Leoncie hopes to create more jobs for the people in her community and she also hopes to earn more profits than previously.

loans.use: To buy additional sewing machines and clothing items

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio T. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog City. He is 44 years old. Gregorio is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Gregorio owns & operates a business harvesting and selling raw rubber and making and selling native food known as "calamay" (made from coco milk, sugar and ground sticky rice). Sometimes he makes native vinegar from the coco sap and sells it in the local community. Gregorio has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Gregorio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gregorio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gregorio is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Gregorio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mrs. Sang Mech Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan includes 24 people who all live in Prachum Angk village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sang M. was selected by all the members as the village bank president. They will all use the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. K. Ben, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow rice to support their family. This family has a problem because they do not have a motorbike. Thus, Mrs. Sang M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike. She is the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. All the members are shown in the picture, but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Gwenotwom C Lalam Christine Group

texts.en: L. Christine is a business woman who is 38 years old and single. She has four children in school. She has owned a grocery store for three years. She is using the loan to purchase grocery items such as tomatoes, charcoal and eggplant to sell. She is adding capital into her business. Her future hope is to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items

loans.name: Isi

texts.en: Isi has a good relationship with LAPO. She is 58 years old and married with five children. Her children attend school and they are excelling in school. Her husband is an electrician and he also supports their home. She sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. she is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and groceries.She hopes to own a super market in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Gwenotwom A Lawino Teddy Group

texts.en: L. Teddy is the group representative of seven members of the group. She is 35 years old and married with three children, all in school. She also has five dependants. Two of her dependants go to school. She makes local brew for sale. She has been in her business for over 20 years. Her business is seasonal due to the scarcity of the ingredients (millet, sorghum, and so forth). So she is using the loan to purchase millet and sorghum in large quantities for her business. She hopes to obtain livestock like goats and cows in the future.

loans.use: To purchase millet and sorghum

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
