CELIA ES LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO ELLA ES MADRE SOLTERA VIVE EN CASA PROPIA Y REALIZA MUCHAS ACTIVIDADES, ES PEINADORA EN SU SALON ADEMAS DE SER PROMOTORA DE COSMETICOS, TIENE 2 HIJOS MENORES A LOS QUE ESTA CRIANDO ACTUALMENTE, CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA PRODUCTOS DE BELLEZA PARA SU SALON.

LA SRA. RAQUEL SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE ROPA Y JUGUETES USADOS QUE VENDE EN LAS FERIAS QUE SE INSTALAN EN LOS DIFERENTES BARRIO DEL PLAN 3000, TIENE SU HIJO QUE VA A LA PRIMARIA, ELLA DESEA AHORRAR Y GENERAR MAS INGRESOS PARA BRINDARLE UNA MEJOR OPORTUNIDAD A SU HIJO, CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA PAQUETES DE JUGUETES USADOS PARA PODER VENDER EN LAS DISTINTAS FERIAS. 

LA SRA. MARIA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE COMIDA DURANTE LA NOCHE, ELLA SACA AFUERA DE SU CASA MESAS Y SILLAS Y VENDE POLLO FRITO Y HAMBURGUESAS DESDE LAS 18:00 HASTA LAS 23:00, ELLA ESTA MUY CONTENTA CON LA OPORTUNIDAD QUE SE LE DA AL RECIBIRLA EN EL GRUPO, CON EL CREDITO COMPRARA PRODUCTOS DE PRIMERA NECESIDAD PARA PREPARAR SUS PLATOS Y PODER VENDERLOS.

TODAS LAS SOCIAS SON PERSONAS RESPONSABLES Y DINAMICAS QUE COMPRARAN MERCADERIA Y PODER ASI INCREMENTAR SU CAPITAL DE TRABAJO, ESTAN MUY AGRADECIDAS CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
The “Las Dinámicas” communal bank is in its second loan cycle within the institution. The women are noted for being very supportive among themselves. When one of them is late with her payment or has a problem of some kind, the others pay for the person who is unable to. Celia is the group president. She is a single mother, lives in her own home, and is engaged in many activities: she’s a hairdresser in her beauty salon but she also sells cosmetics. She has two, minor children that she is raising. She will use the funds to buy beauty products for her salon. Raquel sells clothing and used toys in the various markets that are set up in various Plan 3000 neighborhoods. She has a son in elementary school. She wants to save up and generate higher income in order to offer her son better opportunities. She will use the funds to buy packages of used toys to sell in the various markets. María sells prepared meals at night. She sets up tables and chairs outside her house and sells fried chicken and hamburgers from 6pm until 11pm. She is very happy with the opportunity that she has been given by being accepted into the group. She will use the funds to buy ingredients for her dishes. All of the members are responsible, dynamic people that will buy merchandise in order to increase their working capital. They are very grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in them by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics.

loans.name: Eva Felicita

texts.es:
DOÑA EVA ES UNA AGRICULTORA Y ACOPIADORA DE GRANOS BASICOS DE LA ZONA DE CHINANDEGA  ES MADRE SOLTERA DE 4 HIJOS LOS CULAES MANTIENE CON EL ESFUERZO DEÇ SU TRABAJO  
 EL CREDITO LO SOLICITA PARA EL ACOPIO DE FRIJOLES Y COMPRA DE INSUMOS PARA LA TEMPORADA DE SIEMBRA
texts.en:
Mrs. Eva is a farmer and harvester of grains in bulk from the Chinandega area. She is a single mother of four children who she supports through her work efforts. She is seeking a loan for the collection of beans and the purchase of supplies for the planting season.

Translated from Spanish by Flavia Garcia, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beans and rent areas for planting

loans.name: Nathalie

texts.fr: S. Nathalie est née le 9 septembre 1960 et vit depuis 19 ans à Godomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Mariée à HOUNSOU Jacques, un chauffeur, Nathalie est mère de quatre enfants et a un autre enfant à sa charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Nathalie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Nathalie n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Nathalie vend des condiments (tomates fraîches, piments, épices, etc.), de l'huile de palme et des feuilles de bissap à son domicile. Nathalie s’approvisionne à Malanville, au nord du Bénin, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Nathalie exerce cette activité depuis 10 ans.  Nathalie a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Nathalie sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Nathalie S. was born September 9th, 1960, and has been living in Godomey, a city in the Abomey Calavi commune of Benin, for 19 years. Nathalie is married to Jacques Hounsou, a driver, and is the mother of four. She also supports one additional child. All of the children attend school. Nathalie lives with her children and her husband. The couple share responsibility for the household expenses. Nathalie never went to school. To earn a living, Nathalie sells condiments (fresh tomatoes, hot pepper, spices, etc.), palm oil and bissap (hibiscus flower) leaves out of her home. She buys her stock in Malanville, in northern Benin, and at Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. This has been her work for 10 years. Nathalie has already received one loan from ALIDé, which she paid back. She is now asking for a second loan from ALIDé, in order to increase her product inventory and better meet her clients’ needs.

Translated from French by Chelsea Rosendale, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing 8 baskets of tomatoes, 3 50-liter jugs of palm oil and 20 bags of bissap leaves.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en: Carlos is 37 years old and lives in his own house. He is building another house on his grandfather's land. When he was very young, Carlos went to Argentina to work for 10 years. When he returned to Paraguay, he used his savings to open a business so that he could live in his own city. Carlos sells CDs, radios, cell phones and other electronics from a stand in the local market. He began the business more than 10 years ago on his own initiative, as the town did not have an electronics salesman. Today, he has an established client base, thanks to his good service. This loan will be used to purchase merchandise for his store including radios, cell phones and cell phone accessories.

loans.use: To purchase electronics to sell such as radios and cell phone accessories

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Florencia, pertenece al banco comunal  “NUEVA VISION DE URUBAMBA”, nuestra socia está ubicado en el corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, Urubamba está a 1 hora 10 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 57 años de edad, ella es viuda y tiene 5 hijos de los cuales  4 de ellos son independientes y vive con uno de 19 años de edad, nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, nuestra socia vende verduras, ella lleva habas, arvejas, zanahorias y todo tipo de verdura a la provincia de la  Convención Quillabamba, la socia  trabaja con esta modalidad hace ya 13 años, compra las verduras en la provincia de Urubamba y las lleva a vender a Quillabamba. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar al por mayor verduras y venderlas. 

Nuestro socio agradece  la oportunidad brindada y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Florencia belongs to the Nueva Vision de Urubamba Communal Bank, which is located in the heart of the sacred valley of the Incas. Urubamba is one hour and ten minutes from the city of Cusco. She is a 57 year old widow, and she has five children. Four of the children are independent, and she lives with her 19 year old child. She alternates her activities between the household and her small business. She sells vegetables. She takes beans, peas, carrots, and all types of vegetables to the Convención Quillabamba province. She has worked this way for 13 years. She buys the vegetables in the Urubamba province and takes them to Quillabamba to sell. She is requesting the loan to buy more vegetables wholesale to sell. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more vegetables wholesale to sell

loans.name: E Retoño Group

texts.es:
EL BANCO D. EMPRENDIMIENTO "EL RETOÑO" SE ENCUENTRAN EN SU 5TO CICLO, ES UN GRUPO UNIDO QUE AL PASAR LOS CICLOS HAN IDO DEPURANDO SOCIAS QUE NO CUMPLIAN HASTA QUEDAR LAS PERSONAS MÁS RESPONSABLES Y SOLIDARIAS ENTRE SI, TODOS VIVEN EN LA URBANIZACION D. "EL RECREO" UNA ZONA ALEJADA D. LA CIUDAD. 

LA SEÑORA MARIA DEL CARMEN ES LA NUEVA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO, ELLA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA D. COMIDA CENA ENTRE SEMANA Y LOS FINES D. SEMANA VEND. COMIDA EN LAS MAÑANAS YA QUE PREPARA PATASCA, EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO ES PARA LA COMPRA D. PRODUCTOS D. PRIMERA NECESIDAD Y ASI PODER PREPARAR SUS RIQUISIMOS PLATOS. 

EL SEÑOR LUIS ES UN INTEGRANTE ANTIGUO QUE TIENE SU PEQUEÑO NEGOCIO D. REPARACIÓN D. CELULARES Y VENTA D. REPUESTOS EN EL MERCADO DEL PLAN 3000, EL DESTINO DLE CREDITO ES PARA LA COMPRA D. HERRAMIENTAS Y REPUESTOS QUE UTILIZARA EN LA REPARACION D. LOS CELULARES. 

LA SRA. NOEMI ES SOCIA ANTIGUA QUE TIENE UNA TIENDA D. ABARROTES EN EL BARRIO, SU TIENDA ES BIEN SURTIDA, ELLA SE CARACTERIZA POR SER UNA PERSONA MUY REPSONSABLE TIENE A SU CARGO DOS HIJOS Y UN NIETO D. HIJA QUE SE ENCUENTRA EN ESPAÑA, SU SUEÑO PODER PONER UN MICROMERCADO EN LA URBANIZACION PUESTO QUE ELLA CUENTA CON MUCHOS CLIENTES Y SU TIENDAS ES D. LAS MAS CONOCIDAS EN LA URBANIZACIÓN, EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO ES PARA LA COMPRA D. ABARROTES AL POR MAYOR.

TODAS LAS SOCIAS SON RESPONSABLES Y TRABAJADORAS, ESTAN AGRADECIDAS CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
The entrepreneurial group "El Retoño" is on its fifth cycle. It is a unified group that, as cycles pass, has removed members that do not participate until the most responsible and supportive persons are left. They all live in the "El Recreo" housing development in an area away from the city. Mrs. Maria del Carmen is the new president of the group. She focuses on the sale of dinner during the week. On weekends she serves breakfast, preparing Patasca [a nutritious sheep and beef soup]. The loan is for the purchase of basic products so that she can prepare her delicious dishes. Mr. Luis is a long time member who owns a small business repairing cell phones and selling parts in the Plan 3000 [an area in the city of Santa Cruz] market. The loan is for the purchase of tools and parts for cell phone repair. Mrs. Noemi is a long time member who has a grocery store in the neighborhood, her store is well stocked. She considers herself a responsible person, caring for two children and the grandson of a daughter who is in Spain. Her dream is to open a mini market in the development since she can count on so many customers, her store is one of the most well known in the area. The loan is for the purchase of groceries in bulk. All of the partners are responsible and hardworking, they are grateful to Emprender and Kiva for their support and for awarding the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Flavia G., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products to prepare food

loans.name: Concepcion Aracely

texts.es:
Concepción H. de 41 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento solo cuenta con luz y agua como servicio básico. Su esposo trabaja con ella en el negocio.

Concepción hace años se quedo sin empleo pero decidió no quedarse estancada y comenzó con la venta elaboración y venta de chifles.

Ahora ella reparte los chifles a los restaurantes y tiendas de Guayaquil. Trabaja todos los días desde las 05h00 hasta las 12h00. Entrega 300 fundas diarias de chifles. Una de las dificultades en el negocio es la competencia.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar plátano y aceite para poder producir mas chifles para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener su propia marca registrada.
texts.en:
Concepción H., age 41, lives in the outskirts of the city on Guayaquil's Perimetral highway. Her house is made of concrete, and she only has the basic services of electricity and water. Her husband works with her in the business. Years ago Concepción was left without a job. She decided not to get stuck that way, and she started making and selling plantain chips. She now distributes the plantain chips to restaurants and stores in Guayaquil. She works everyday from 5:00 a.m. until 12:00 a.m. She delivers 300 cases of plantain chips daily. One of the difficulties in the business is the competition. With the loan she wants to buy bananas and oil to be able to make more plantain chips for her business. In the future she wants to have her own registered brand.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bananas and oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 15 bags of roselle hibiscus leaves and 10 bags of maize

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr: A. Chantal est née en 1975 à Dogbo mais vit depuis 10 ans à Gbodjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à AMESSIAMENOU K. Joseph, un transitaire, elle est mère de trois enfants et a trois autres enfants à sa charge.  Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Chantal vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure  ensemble les charges de la famille.  Chantal vend des vêtements et des sous-vêtements par le système de distribution. C’est à Lomé au Togo, pays à coté du Bénin, qu’elle s’approvisionne.  Chantal exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans, et est à son premier crédit à ALIDé.  Chantal sollicite ce crédit en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle. Plus tard, Chantal ambitionne gagner une grande part de marché.
texts.en:
Chantal A. was born in 1975 in Dogbo, but has lived for 10 years in Gbodjè in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to K. Joseph Amessiamenou, a forwarding agent, she is the mother of three children, and has three additional children in her care. All of the children are in school. Chantal lives together with her husband and children. The couple provide for the family together. Chantal sells clothing and undergarments through the distribution system. She gets her supplies in Lomé, Togo, a country bordering Benin. Chantal has run this business for 5 years, and is on her first loan with ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). Chantal is seeking this loan in order to strengthen her business and better respond to the numerous demands of her clientele. In the future, Chantal aspires to gain a larger market share.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 dozen sets of undergarments and one batch of clothing (infants' and children's outfits)

loans.name: Kai

texts.fr: D. Kai est née en 1961 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin, mais vit depuis 10 ans à Womey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à AGBASSA Joseph, une géomètre, Kai est mère de cinq enfants et a trois autres enfants à sa charge.  Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Kai vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Kai vend des feuilles de tisane (plantes de la médecine traditionnelle) et des poteries à son domicile. C’est à Glagoué et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Kai s’approvisionne. Kai exerce cette activité depuis 9 ans. Kai a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Kai n’arrive plus à satisfaire toute la demande de sa clientèle compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. C’est ce qui amène Kai à solliciter un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Kai D. was born in 1961 in Ouidah, a historical city in Benin, but has lived for 10 years in Womey in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Joseph Agbassa, a land surveyor, Kai is the mother of five children and has three additional children in her care. All of the children are in school. Kai lives together with her husband and children. The couple provide for the family together. To meet her needs, Kai sells tisane leaves (a plant used in traditional medicine) and pottery at her house. It is in Glagoué and at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, that Kai gets her supplies. Kai has run this business for 9 years. Kai has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. Kai is no longer able to satisfy all the demands of her clientele, thanks to the limited financial means she has. This is what has led Kai to seek a second loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 2 dozen sets of "canari" pottery and jars, 3 bags of tree leaves, and 3 bags of tree roots

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is an entrepreneur from Mukachevo. She sells footwear in one of the local markets in her hometown, right next to a bus station. Her inventory is always in high demand among market customers. Eva launched this small venture six years ago. Presently, she has about 50,000 grivnyas in turnover capital. 

Eva is a dedicated entrepreneur who has a desire to achieve further expansion, pushes to conquer problems and strives for a successful venture. One of her long-term plans is to continue expanding her trade. She is ready to take on even more responsibility to achieve her goals. Today Eva is requesting a loan of 8,500 grivnyas to increase the assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her vending kiosk.

loans.use: To increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married with two children. He lives in Vasilyevka, the south-eastern part of Ukraine, where he runs a grocery kiosk selling noodles, sugar, oil, and grits in the local market. In the business for 12 years, he can boast competitive prices that help him find and keep his loyal clientele.  

Alexander is seeking a loan of 9,500 Grivnyas to increase his turnover capital. He has a family to provide for and works hard to meet all of their needs including saving for his kids’ college. One of the biggest advantages of his small enterprise is his own truck which makes transportation efficient.

loans.use: to increase his working capital

loans.name: We Will Do It Group

texts.en:
Christina O. is the leader of group five borrowers called "We Will Do It." She is 35 years old, married with four children between the ages of 4 and 15 years old  — nursery school to 5th grade. Christina, who is shown on the right holding the sign, could not continue her own education past 4th grade due to poverty. 

Her business is the sale of foodstuffs such as salt, pepper, oil, and seasonings  She buys her goods wholesale and sells retail on a table in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia  She has been running her business for four years and hopes to grow it into a store in the near future.

Christina started by selling cold water with a small amount of money, but later added foodstuffs. She positions her goods on her table in an attractive way so that customers are interested in buying from her. Christina will use this loan to purchase additional salt, onions, pepper and seasonings for resale. She dreams of giving her children a good education and building a house for her family.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional salt, onions, pepper and seasonings for resale.

loans.name: Denise Delhia

texts.fr: C. Denise Delhia est née le 9 octobre 1961 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Denise Delhia vit depuis 20 ans au quartier Agla à Cotonou.  Mariée à NADOHOU Steve, professeur au Lycée Technique de Coulibaly, Denise Delhia est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Denise Delhia vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Denise Delhia vend divers produits (lait, sucre, bougies, piles, fournitures scolaires, etc.) dans sa boutique à Agla. De façon secondaire, Denise Delhia vend de la friperie (jeans, tee-shirts, etc).  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, pays à coté du Bénin, que Denise Delhia s’approvisionne.  Denise Delhia exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans et a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Denise Delhia sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour élever le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients ; ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Denise Delhia C. was born on 9 October 1961 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Denise Delhia has lived for 20 years in the Agla district in Cotonou. Married to Steve Nadohou, a teacher at the Lycée Technique (Technical School) of Coulibaly, Denise Delhia is the mother of two children, both of whom are in school and in her care. Denise Delhia lives together with her husband and children. The couple provide for the family together. Denise Delhia sells various goods (milk, sugar, candles, batteries, school supplies, etc.) at her store in Agla. As a second activity, Denise Delhia also sells second-hand clothing (jeans, t-shirts, etc.). She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and in Lomé, Togo, a country bordering Benin. Denise Delhia has run this business for 15 years and has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. Denise Delhia is seeking a second loan with ALIDÉ to raise the level of her business and better respond to the various needs of her customers; this will allow her to generate a larger income.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two boxes of milk cartons, one carton of sugar packets, and one dozen jeans and shirts

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya G. is a single mother in Nikopol, Ukraine. She owns a clothing business offering merchandise at retail prices at two different markets of her home town. She launched this business five years ago. Presently, Lidiya has 30,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital and her income amounts to 10,000 Grivnyas. 

Lidiya is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to diversify her clothing and footwear merchandise and boost her sales this spring following the slack, slow winter season. She is hoping to open a third sales facility and expand her trade as a result. Lidiya is a borrower of integrity and responsibility with a good credit record.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: G.s. Sagrada Familia Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario compuesto por dos personas, tienen 20 créditos y es uno de los más antiguos de la institución, son excelentes clientes. Aurora tiene una pulpería desde hace más de 20 años con la cual ha apoyado el sustento familiar, vive con su familia. Su cónyuge es obrero y  da su aporte para el  bienestar familiar. Su amiga que es la persona con la que trabaja para salir adelante. Amparo tiene la su actividad es el destace de cerdo, elaborar comida y  dulces, vive con su familia, por lo que está a cargo de sus tres hijos donde tienen  uno de los servicios básicos primarios como es la energía y su cónyuge labora como obrero en el campo y con su salario ayuda al sustento también de la familia.
texts.en:
This supportive group made up of two people. They have twenty loans and it is one of the institution's oldest; they are excellent clients. Aurora has had a local store for more than 20 years with which she has supported her family. She lives with her family. Her spouse is a laborer and he does his part for the family's wellbeing. Her friend is the person she works with to get ahead. Amparo's activity is butchering pigs, and making food and sweets. She lives with her family and takes care of her three children where they have one of the basic services, such as electricity. Her spouse works as a laborer in the fields and with his salary he helps to support the family as well.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Our God Is Good Group

texts.en:
Helena W. sells fruit and vegetables, such as plantains, cassava and lettuce, at the Red Light Market which is the largest market in Liberia. She has eight children between the ages of 2 years and 23 years.  In addition to her children, Helena also supports her parents.

Helena says she sells high quality food at good prices, which keeps customers returning. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more fruits and vegetables. She hopes that this loan will help her to buy land and start her own farm in the future. In addition, her dream is for all of her children to be educated. 

Helena is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Our God is Good". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Helena is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Maria Angelita

texts.es:
Maria Angelita tiene 22 años de edad, es casada y vive junto a su esposo y a su menor hijo en el caserío Chepito Alto del distrito de Mórrope, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la venta de combustible en su domicilio desde hace un año. Ella nos comenta que la iniciativa de su negocio nació debido a la falta de agua para regar los sembríos de la zona. Los agricultores han hecho pozos y riegan con ellos sus cultivos, pero para realizar esta a cción deben utilizar motores, los cuales necesitan de gasolina para funcionar.

Este negocio le brinda ingresos adicionales que son de mucha ayuda para el sostenimiento de su familia ya que su esposo, al igual que la mayoría de hombres de a zona, trabaja como obrero agrícola y lo que percibe no le basta para sustentar la economía familiar.

Maria Angelita desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más combustible y aceite, con los cuales pueda seguir atendiendo la demanda de su producto. Por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el logro de su objetivo.

Ella es una joven madre trabajadora, responsable y muy entregada a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Maria Angelita is 22 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and their minor child in the small town Chepito Alto of the district of Mórrope, located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She has been selling fuel from her house for more than a year. She tells us that the idea for her business was born from the lack of water to irrigate the plantings in the area. The farmers have made wells and they irrigate their crops with them. In order to do this, they have to use motors, which need gasoline to work. This business has brought her additional income which are a big help for the family's support. Her husband, like most of the men in the area, works as an agricultural laborer and what he makes is not enough to support the family economy. Maria Angelita wishes to grow her business with the purchase of more fuel and oil, with which she can continue to attend to the demand for her product. Due to this she is asking Edpyme Alternativa for the first time for a loan of 1000 nuevos soles. She plans on using it to acheive her goal. She is a young, hardworking mother and very dedicated to her family. Her biggest wish is to give her family a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase gasoline and oil to grow her business.

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married with a grown-up son. She lives in Kamenka and owns four big spacious greenhouses. Natalya grows early spring vegetables, e.g., tomatoes, radishes, etc., for sale in her region. Her greenhouses are heated which facilitates her farming experience. Natalya is a hard worker. She has been in the farming business for 26 years. Currently, she has 85,000 grivnyas invested in her enterprise. Annually, Natalya spends 8,000 – 13,000 grivnyas on seeds and film.

Natalya is seeking a 10,000 grivnya loan to purchase seeds and polyethylene film for her greenhouses. She is hoping to re-cover her greenhouses ensuring heat preservation inside of them. One of Natalya’s long-term plans is construction of new greenhouses in the future.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and polyethylene film for her greenhouse

loans.name: Daysi

texts.es:
Daysi vende verduras y esencialmente plátanos en el mercado Mayoreo donde a diario apertura sus ventas desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana con la finalidad de obtener sus ingresos para el mantenimiento de su hogar.

Actualmente ella está solicitando un crédito que será invertido para la compra de los plátanos y por esta razón espera que el crédito le sea otorgado y así continuará en sus ventas en el mercado.
texts.en:
Daysi sells vegetables and fruits, primarily bananas, daily in the Mayoreo market. She starts very early in the morning in order to obtain her income to maintain her home. At present, she is asking for a loan that she will use for the purchase of bananas and for that reason she hopes that the loan is granted to her so that she can continue her selling in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick Clarke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Laurence

texts.fr: H. Laurence est née le 10 août 1971 et réside à Vodjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à AHOSSI Edmond, un agent commercial, Laurence est mère de deux enfants et a un autre enfant à sa charge.  Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Laurence vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Laurence a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Pour contribuer aux charges familiales, Laurence vend divers articles (galettes d'arachides, fournitures scolaires, conserves, etc.) et des produits cosmétiques à son quartier. Laurence s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Laurence exerce cette activité depuis 4 ans.  Laurence est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Laurence sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé en vue de renforcer ses activités et de se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges.
texts.en:
Laurence H. was born on 10 August 1971 and lives in Vodjè in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Edmond Ahossi, a commercial agent, Laurence is the mother of two children, and has one other child in her care. All of the children are in school. Laurence lives together with her children and husband. The couple provide for the family together. Laurence ended her studies in secondary school. To contribute to meeting the family's expenses, Laurence sells various items (peanut cookies, school supplies, canned goods, etc.) and cosmetics in her district. Laurence gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She has run this business for 4 years, and is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), having already obtained four loans, all of which she repaid properly. Laurence is seeking a fifth loan with ALIDÉ in order to strengthen her business and generate a larger income by raising her sales.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy body lotions, school supplies, and canned goods

loans.name: Estela Ofelia

texts.es:
La señora Estela M. es una dama muy trabajadora que se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras y especialmente a la venta de papayas en su propio puesto en el mercado Mayoreo de Managua.

Ella se ha destacado por ser una dama muy trabajadora que ha sabido salir adelante en el negocio de venta de las papayas y está solicitando el crédito para ser invertido en la compra de dichas papayas y así continuar en su negocio en su localidad.
texts.en:
Estela M. is a very hard-working lady, whose business is selling vegetables and fruits, especially papayas, from her own stall at Managua's Mayoreo market. She stands out for being a very hard-working woman who has figured out how to get ahead in her business of selling papayas. She is requesting this loan so that she can invest the funds to purchase more papayas, and thus continue her business in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying papayas

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en: For seven years, Thomas G. has had a CD and DVD business at the Red Light Market, which is the biggest market in Liberia. He is 19 years old, single, and has no children. He currently attends 11th grade. He says that he is friendly to his customers and that he sells the discs at a low price, which keeps people returning. Thomas plans to use his 5,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 25,000 LRD group loan to buy more CDs and DVDs. He hopes that this loan will allow him to keep paying his school fees. Thomas is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "God is Able". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Thomas is the one holding the sign. Papa K. is inset at the upper right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Sabine Gloria

texts.fr: D. Sabine Gloria est née le 3 septembre 1971 et réside à Sikècodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 38 ans.  Sabine Gloria est mariée à KINIFO Michel, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés.  Sabine Gloria vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Sabine Gloria a arrêté les classes au cours primaire. Pour contribuer aux charges familiales, Sabine Gloria vend des produits vivriers (maïs, riz) à son domicile. Sabine Gloria s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Sabine Gloria exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans. Sabine Gloria a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé ; ce crédit a été bien remboursé.  Sabine Gloria sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Sabine Gloria D. was born on 3 September 1971 and has lived in Sikècodji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for 38 years. She is married to Michel Kinifo, and is the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. Sabine Gloria lives together with her children and husband. The couple provide for the family together. Sabine Gloria ended her studies in primary school. To contribute to meeting the family's expenses, Sabine Gloria sells basic staples (maize, rice) at her home. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Sabine Gloria has run this business for 15 years. She has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners); this loan was repaid properly. Sabine Gloria is seeking a second loan with ALIDÉ to strengthen her business and respond to the high demand of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and rice

loans.name: Faucto

texts.es:
Faucto H. es un caballero muy trabajador y propietario de una pulpería en el mercado Mayoreo en Managua donde atiende a muchos clientes que le visitan por lo que debe de contar con el inventario suficiente para suplir las necesidades de sus clientes.


Está solicitando un crédito para ser invertido en la compra de los productos y especialmente en la compra de productos lácteos como el queso para ofertarlo en su pulpería y de esta manera generar sus ingresos para continuar manteniendo el negocio.
texts.en:
Faucto H. is a very hard-working gentleman; he has a general store in Managua's Mayoreo market where he tends to his customers. He must have adequate inventory to meet their needs. He is asking for funding to buy products, especially dairy products like cheese, to offer in his store in order to generate higher income and continue to support the business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dairy products.

loans.name: Power From God Group

texts.en: For 10 years, Krubo T. has been selling charcoal at the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She is 39 years old, married and has five children who range in age from 1 to 18 years old. She is very friendly to her customers which keeps them returning. Krubo plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more charcoal. Her goal is to have all of her children attend school and to be able to open her own shop one day. Krubo is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Power from God". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Krubo is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal

loans.name: Griselda Del Socorro

texts.es:
En el mercado Mayoreo, la señora Griselda se dedica con gran ahínco al negocio de venta de discos compactos de videos y música ofertados en su propio establecimiento donde a diario vende los discos con el fin de obtener ingresos para el mejoramiento de su nivel de vida y el de su familia.

Ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de los discos compactos para continuar ofreciéndolos en el mercado y así realizar sus ventas con el fin de obtener el ingreso necesario para el mantenimiento de su hogar.
texts.en:
Griselda sells CDs and DVDs in the Mayoreo market every day in order to generate income to improve her family's quality of life. She is asking for funding to buy CDs in order to be able to continue to offer them for sale and earn income sufficient to support her household.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy CDs.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more soap-making products

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes O. is a single parent with two children. She has received a senior high education. Agnes sells foodstuffs such as tomatoes, onions, pepper, and provisions at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Agnes uses her income to pay school fees and utility bills. Agnes will use the loan to purchase more provisions and food supplies to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to save in order to reinvest in the business and to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and food supplies to sell

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: K. Nicole est née le 4 décembre 1971 et réside depuis 18 ans à Sikècodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Nicole est mariée à HOUNTONDJI Philippe et est mère de quatre enfants et a un autre enfant à sa charge.  Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Nicole vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Nicole a arrêté les classes au cours primaire. Pour contribuer aux charges familiales, Nicole vend de nourriture (pâte rouge de maïs et piron fait à base de farine de manioc) dans son quartier. Nicole s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Nicole exerce cette activité depuis 8 ans.  Nicole a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Nicole sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour augmenter sa production et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Nicole K. was born on 4 December 1971 and has lived for 18 years in Sikècodji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Nicole is married to Philippe Hountondji and is the mother of four children, with one additional child in her care. All of the children are in school. Nicole lives together with her children and husband. The couple provide for the family together. Nicole ended her studies in primary school. To contribute to meeting the family's expenses, Nicole sells food (red maize paste and 'piron' - a paste made from manioc flour) in her district. Nicole gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Nicole has run this business for 8 years, and has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. Nicole is seeking a second loan with ALIDÉ to increase her production and better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize, manioc flour, and palm oil

loans.name: Bismark Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Bismark M. se dedica a su negocio de venta de embutidos como huevos y pollo en su propio establecimiento en el mercado Mayoreo de Managua donde se ha ganado la confianza de muchos clientes por ser una persona muy tranquila y trabajador.

Está solicitando el crédito para ser invertido en la compra de los embutidos como huevos y pollo para continuar en su venta y así satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes que a diario le visitan en el mercado.
texts.en:
Bismark M. sell eggs and chicken in his own establishment in Managua's Mayoreo market; he has won over the trust of many regular customers because he's a calm and hard-working person. He is asking for funds to buy eggs and chicken to sell thereby meeting daily customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eggs and chicken.

loans.name: Grace Women Group

texts.en:
Kebbeh M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Grace Women. She is 40 years old, single, and has three children who range in age from 4 to 22 years old.

For fifteen years, Kebbeh has been selling oil, rice, and peppers at the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She is very friendly to her customers, which keeps them returning.

Kebbeh plans to use her 7000 LRD portion of this 33,000 LRD group loan to buy more oil, rice, and peppers. Her goal is to grow her business and to have all of her children attend school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kebbeh is the one holding the sign. Weedor J.'s photo is inset at the upper right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socioeconomic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and LEAP puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more oil, rice, and peppers

loans.name: Juana Paula

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de Managua, la señora Juana Paula A. se dedica con gran empeño a vender frutas y verduras en su propio local donde a diario ofrece sus productos a los clientes y ha buscado la manera de cómo surtir sus ventas para obtener más ingresos para el mantenimiento de su hogar.

Está solicitando un crédito para ser invertido en la compra de las verduras y de esta manera continuar satisfaciendo las necesidades de sus clientes en el mercado.
texts.en:
In the Mayoreo Market in Managua, Mrs. Juana Paula A. sells fruits and vegetables with great dedication and effort at her own stall, where she offers her products daily to her customers; she has looked for ways to have a better assortment of products in order to increase her income for her household expenses. She is requesting a loan to invest in purchasing vegetables so she can and satisfy the needs of her customers in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vegetables

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr: S. Yvette est née en 1969 et réside à Sedami à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 41 ans.  Yvette est divorcée et mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés.  Yvette vit seule avec ses enfants. Yvette a arrêté les classes au cours primaire. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Yvette vend de l’Akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) dans son quartier. Yvette s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Yvette exerce cette activité depuis 20 ans.  Yvette a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Yvette sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux répondre à la demande sans cesse croissante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Yvette S. was born in 1969 and has lived for 41 years in Sedami in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Yvette is divorced and has two children, both of whom are in school. Yvette lives alone with her children. She ended her studies in primary school. To provide for her children, Yvette sells 'akassa' (a local food made from cornstarch) in her district. Yvette gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Yvette has run this business for 20 years, and has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. Yvette is seeking a second loan with ALIDÉ to strengthen her business and better respond to the constantly increasing demand of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Dania Del Rosario

texts.es: Dania Del Rosario A. Avilés tiene 52 años, su actividad económica es la venta de ropa, y prendas de plata. Ella es una mujer luchadora y triunfadora, además anteriormente se dedicaba a una pulpería, pero al no tener los resultados esperados, decide comenzar con la venta de ropa, ya que era favorecedor para ella pues tenía la experiencia necesaria con el negocio anterior, ella se ha llenado mucho valor y así comenzar un medio de ingreso.  Los sueños son lo que tiene siempre en mente como seguirle proporcionando mejoras a su vivienda. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima y aumentar su clientela.
texts.en:
Dania Del Rosario A. A. is 52 years old. Her economic activity is selling clothes and silver jewelry. She is a fighter and a winner. Perviously she had a small store, but when she didn't get the results she hoped for, she decided to start selling clothes. This suited her and she had the necessary experience with her previous business. She took courage and started to have a source of income. Her dreams are what is always on her mind such as improving her home. The financing she is asking for is for the purchase of raw materials to increase her clientele.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: M Y H 4 Group

texts.en:
Juana is the coordinator of her group "M y H" ("M and H"), which is short for "Mujeres y Hombres" which means "Men and Women" Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in Hato Mayor, a poor agricultural area where running water is not potable and electricity is unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure. She is a single mother with two children.

Juana sells cosmetics. She is excited to be borrowing her third loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by using the loan capital to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She will use the profits to construct a new roof for her home and buy school supplies for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Cosmetics

loans.name: Determine Women Group

texts.en: Klubo N. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Determine Women. She is 38 years old and married with four children aged 7 to 19 years old, with educational levels of kindergarten through 10th grade. Klubo is a high school graduate. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign. Klubo's business is the sale of cold water, both wholesale and retail. She buys sacks (plastic bags) of water from mineral water companies, then cools the bags in a cold storage container and sells to retailers in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She has been running her business for three years and hopes to establish a real estate business in the future. Klubo will use this loan to purchase additional sacks of water for resale. She dreams of giving her children a better education so that they can have a good future. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional sacks of water to sell

loans.name: Rosa Enma

texts.es:
Rosa tiene 56 años de edad, es casada y vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos en el caserío Sime, ubicado en el distrito de Pítipo, a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se ha dedicado durante más de 20 años a la crianza y comercialización de ovejas, empezó comprando ovejas para criarlas y poco a poco su cría aumentó. Actualmente vende sus animales a los negociantes que visitan la zona regularmente. Este negocio es de mucha ayuda para la economía de su familia ya que su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y esta actividad no les provee de ingresos permamentes.

Rosa desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más ovejas, pero no cuenta con el capital suficiente para realizar esta acción, por este motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Ella es una mujer responsable, entregada a su familia y que gusta mucho de su trabajo. Su mayor anhelo es seguir ayudando a su familia para darles una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Rosa is 56 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and two children in the town of Sime, located in the district of Pitipo, 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For more than 20 years she has been raising and selling sheep. She began buying sheep to raise and little by little the brood grew. At present she sells her animals to businesspeople who visit the area regularly. This business really helps her family's finances since her husband works in farming and this activity does not provide permanent income. Rosa wants to grow her business with the purchase of more sheep, but she doesn't have enough capital to do this. This is why she sees the need, for the first time, to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles to help her achieve her goal. She is a responsible woman, dedicated to her family and she really enjoys her job. Her biggest wish is to continue helping her family to give them a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of sheep to grow her business.

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.fr: S. Euphrasie est née en 1972 et réside depuis 38 ans à Sikècodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Euphrasie est veuve et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge. Euphrasie vit seule avec ses enfants. Euphrasie a arrêté les classes au cours primaire. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Euphrasie vend par méthode de distribution, des bijoux et d’autres articles dans son quartier.  Elle vend aussi et surtout des fruits (bananes, oranges, etc.). Euphrasie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Euphrasie exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans. Euphrasie a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Euphrasie sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour améliorer ses activités et acheter plus de bijoux et de fruits.
texts.en:
Euphrasie S. was born in 1972 and has lived for 38 years in Sikècodji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Euphrasie is a widow and has four children, all of whom are in school and in her care. Euphrasie lives alone with her children. She ended her studies in primary school. To provide for her children, Euphrasie sells jewelry and other items in her locality, through the distribution system. She also sells fruit (bananas, oranges, etc.). Euphrasie gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She has run this business for 5 years, and has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. Euphrasie is seeking a second loan with ALIDÉ to improve her business and buy more jewelry and fruit.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit (bananas, oranges, etc.)

loans.name: Khary

texts.fr: Madame Khary G. est une femme de 42 ans qui habite à Yoff plus précisément dans le quartier de Dagoudane. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC Yoff depuis mai 2009 et n’a jamais bénéficié de prêt. Elle est divorcée et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 17 et20 ans. Depuis deux ans elle s’exerce dans le commerce de chaussures, de tissus et de parfums. Elle est aussi ouvrière  a l’usine Africamer. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs pour acheter des chaussures de femme et des parfums pour son commerce. Elle a choisi cette activité par passion et aussi pour soutenir sa petite famille
texts.en:
Ms. Khary G. is a 42-year-old woman who lives in Yoff, specifically in the Dagoudane district. She has been a member of the U-IMCEC Yoff savings group since May 2009, and has not had any previous loans. She is divorced and has 2 children whose ages range between 17 and 20 years. For two years, she has run a business selling shoes, fabric, and perfume. She is also a worker at the Africamer factory. She is seeking a loan of 100,000 FCFA to buy women's shoes and perfume for her business. She chose this business because of her interest in it and also to support her small family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia N. sells fresh fish and meat in Elmina. Cecelia has received no formal education. She is single and has two children. Cecelia has been selling fresh fish and meat for some time now. She is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills, as well as other financial obligations of her family. Her loan will be used to buy more fish and meat to be frozen by way of processing. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save money for the education of her children and to acquire a shop for herself.

(In her hand are two fish for display.)

loans.use: To buy more fish and meat to sell

loans.name: By Faith In God Group

texts.en: Momo S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called “By Faith In God”. He is 29 years old and is married with a 10-year-old child who is in the 2nd grade. Momo is a high school graduate waiting to enter university. He and his family live and work in Paynesville, Liberia. In the photo, Momo is the one holding the sign. Stephen K. is inset at lower right. Momo’s business is the sale of general goods such as batteries, candles, milk, sugar and rubber slippers. He buys his goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table to residents of his community. He has been running his business for eleven years and hopes to own a store in the near future. Momo will use this loan to purchase more batteries, candles, milk, sugar and rubber slippers. He dreams of giving his family the best help he can to improve all of their lives. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es: El Sr. José Antonio G. Hernández trabaja para el área de jardinería en un centro turísticos, opera una podadora de césped manual, su estado civil es casado, este crédito lo solicito  para terminar de construir su vivienda, con CEPRODEL es su cuarto crédito y dice sentirse bien con los beneficios que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
José Antonio G. Hernández works as a gardener in tourist centers; he operates a manual lawn mower. He is married and is asking for funding to finish building his house. This is his 4th loan with CEPRODEL and he says he's happy with the benefits that the institution offers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Arely Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Arely del Carmen tiene 43 años de edad, es casada, y tiene dos hijos que tienen edades de 10 y 13 años. Ella se dedica a la compra-venta de ropa usada y zapatos variados, distribuyéndolos de forma ambulante, además de que ofrece en su casa de habitación. La señora Arely dio inicio a este negocio hace seis años, con una parte de ropa usada, hoy en día ya compra hasta dos sacos y gracias a que ha prosperado ahora también vende zapatos. Es importante mencionar, que además de tener los ingresos de este negocio la señora también labora como docente en una escuela. Ella está solicitando este crédito con el objetivo de comprar ropa usada y una de zapatos variados, los cuales serán distribuidos principalmente a las personas que con ella trabajan, ya que ella aprovecha trabajar para distribuir sus productos entre sus compañeras de trabajo. Ella sueña con llegar a tener algún día un tramo en el mercado.
texts.en:
Señora Arely del Carmen is 43 years old. She is married and has two children ages 10 and 13. She buys and sells used clothing and a variety of shoes. She sells her things on foot as well as from her home. Señora Arely started this business six years ago with a portion of used clothes, today she buys a large amount for resal and thanks to her success she also sells shoes. It is important to mention, in addition to the income from this business, Arely is also a teacher at a school. She is seeking this loan in order to buy used clothing and a selection of shoes which she will distribute primarily to the people that she works with that she has already approved to distribute her products among her coworkers. She dreams of having one day having a cart in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Used clothing and shoes

loans.name: Faosiath

texts.fr: A. Faosiath est née en 1975 et vit depuis 13 ans à Sikècodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Faosiath est mariée à SALANON Ulrich, un soudeur, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Faosiath vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Faosiath n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour supporter les charges familiales, Faosiath vend des sachets et divers articles (savons, conserves, etc.) de façon ambulante. Faosiath s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Faosiath exerce cette activité depuis 11 ans. Faosiath a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Faosiath sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Faosiath A. is born in 1975. She has been living for the last 13 years in the Sikècodji district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Faosiath is married to Ulrich Salanon, a welder, and has a child who attends school. Faosiath lives together with her husband and their child. The couple takes care of the family expenses together. Faosiath never attended school. In order to support her family, Faosiath works as a street vendor, selling water packs and various items (soaps, canned food etc). She buys her stock at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been doing it for 11 years. Faosiath had a previous loan from ALIDé, which was duly reimbursed. She is now seeking another loan in order to strengthen her business and to better respond to her customers’ needs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing a stock of soap and other items for sale

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: H. Julienne est née en 1956 et réside depuis 2 ans à Sedjro à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne est mariée à DOMINGO Denis et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Julienne vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Julienne n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour supporter les charges familiales, Julienne vend de la nourriture (riz et akassa fait à base d'amidon de maïs) dans son quartier. Julienne s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Julienne exerce cette activité depuis 10 ans.  Julienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Julienne sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès à ALIDé en vue de renforcer ses activités et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Julienne H. was born in 1956 and has been living in Sedjro in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for two years. She's married to Denis DOMINGO, and she's the mother of three school-attending children. Juliette lives with her children and her husband, and the couple provides for the family expenses together. Juliette never attended school. To support her family, Juliette sells food (rice and akassa, a traditional beninese food, made out of corn flour) in her neighborhood. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international marketplace in Benin. Juliette has been running this business for 10 years. Juliette is a former client of Kiva's partner, ALIDé, who already benefited from four loans, which were repaid without problems. She's seeking her fifth loan from ALIDé, in order to bolster her business and meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, corn, and vegetable oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Augustine K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Togetherness. He is single with five children who range in age from 4 months to 18 years old. He also takes care of his girlfriend and her child.

Augustine has an electronics repair business in the Red Light Market, which is the biggest market in Liberia. He has been running this business for eight years, and he hopes to grow his business into a bigger shop in the near future.

Augustine says he repairs electronics very well in order to encourage customers to continue coming to his shop for repairs. Augustine will use this loan to purchase additional spare parts such as antennas, resistors, and capacitors. He dreams of improving the living conditions of his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Augustine is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socioeconomic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and LEAP puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional spare parts such as antennas, resistors, and capacitors

loans.name: Feliz Group

texts.en: In the city of Paraguarí, a group of women met in order to form a committee and take out a loan. They arranged a meeting to find out about the program, and accepted because it gave them the opportunity to increase their working capital and receive training sessions that would allow them to more fully develop themselves as people. They are very hard-working women, and this is a great opportunity for them, since they have never before received any kind of credit.  The committee is called Felíz (“Happy”), and they are currently in their fifth loan cycle. The group is made up of 18 hard-working, sacrificing women who strive each day to afford a better quality of life to themselves and their families.  All the group members are very active women, and have invested their loans in their respective activities. One of these women is Mrs. Antonia V., who sells fruits and vegetables in the Paraguarí market. She has a stand where she displays her fresh produce, which she buys from other group members. Some of the fruits she sells are oranges, bananas, pineapples and watermelon; some of the vegetables she sells are onions, tomatoes, carrots and hot peppers.  Her sales are very good, and help her pay her household expenses. Antonia says, “A lot of things depend on my income, like food and my children’s clothing and education.” She is a single mother. She is very grateful for this loan, which she used to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.use: Compra de frutas y verduras.

loans.name: Fatou Diop

texts.fr: Madame Fatou Diop S. est une dame de 35 ans qui habite a Yoff Layenne. Elle est sociétaire de   la caisse de l’U-IMCEC Yoff depuis 2003. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants dont l’âgé  varie entre 2 et 8 ans. Après la terminale elle a commence à exercer le commerce de parfums, d’encens et de blousons et ceci depuis 10 ans. Dans un premier temps elle se procurait des produis chez d’autres commerçants qu’elle plaçait, récupérait ses bénéfices et remboursait le capital. Grace aux conseils de son père elle a décidé de solliciter de la mutuelle un prêt de 50 000 frs pour acheter lui-même les produits vendus à des prix plus compétitifs. La réalisation de bénéfices lui permet d’améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou Diop S. is a 35-year-old lady who lives in Yoff Layenne. She has been a member of the U-IMCEC Yoff savings group (one of Kiva's field partners) since 2003. She is married and has two children whose ages range from 2 to 8 years. After finishing high school, she has been selling perfume, incense, jackets, and so on for 10 years. At first, she used to procure her goods from other merchants whom she found, then earned her profit and repaid the capital. Thanks to her father's advice, she has decided to seek a loan through the savings group for 50,000 FCFA to buy the goods herself at more competitive prices. The realization of profits allows her to improve her children's living conditions.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Amparo Nazaria

texts.es:
La señora Amparo Conrrado se desempeña como enfermera y es madre de tres hijos en edad escolar. 
Está solicitando un crédito para invertirlo en la compra de materiales de construcción para mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda y así brindarle un techo digno a sus hijos. 

Ella realizará esta obra porque está comprometida con el bienestar de sus hijos y para ello necesita dicho crédito para comprar a lo inmediato los materiales de construcción y las cerámicas para comenzar con esta labor en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mrs. Amparo Nazario is a registered nurse and the mother of 3 school-aged children. She is married. This loan is to make improvements to her house by buying construction materials and installing tile. Amparo has solicited loans through CEPRODEL for a long time and she says she has benefited greatly, because she makes her payments on time and the interest rates are not too high.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS (SAND, BLOCKS, CEMENT) AND TO PAY THE WORKERS

loans.name: United For Purpose Group

texts.en:
Amos K. is the leader of a group five borrowers called United For Purpose. He is unmarried and has a four-year-old son. Amos could not continue his education past twelfth grade.
 
Amos has a business selling used clothing in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. He has been running this business for four years and hopes to grow his business into a store in the near future.

Amos started with 5000 Liberian Dollars and now has 42,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital. His challenge is that he does not have enough money to buy enough used clothing to meet his customers' needs. Amos will use this loan to purchase more used clothing for sale. He dreams of sending his son to school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Amos is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the nonprofit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional used clothing for sale.

loans.name: Geraldino

texts.en: Geraldino is sixty-three years old and lives in his own house with his wife, who helps him with his business. The couple has two children together.  Geraldino opened his business more than seven years ago because he saw that the area needed a corner store. Since then, his business has been very successful because of his comprehensive product offerings and the good service he provides. Geraldino works hard every day to do the best he can for his family, and, in addition to running the corner store, he buys and sells cattle with his son's help in order to augment his income. He is seeking this loan to purchase more merchandise for his store so he can meet his clients' needs.

loans.use: Purchase merchendise for sale in his corner store

loans.name: Las Jarochas Group

texts.es:
Las Jarochas son un grupo unido de mujeres trabajadoras.  Este grupo está ubicado en la colonia Emiliano Zapata  de la ciudad de  Tierra Blanca VeraC..  

La representante del grupo se llama Cecilia C. S. de 41 años de edad.  Ella es madre soltera, de  3 hijos de los cuales do son dos mujeres y un  varón. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y ropa, y necesita el préstamo para surtir su tienda.  Doña Cecilia comenta que su sueño es ampliar su tienda para que de esa manera se convierta algún día en un mini súper ya que dice que al vivir tan lejos del centro de su ciudad siente que su negocio prospera mas por que las personas preferirán compran en su tienda.

Los integrantes son:  Cristela Rodríguez C. ella vende zapatos, Yaret Q. N. ella vende bolsas y ropa, Petra Cochyuchi V. ella empezara a vender dulces y refrescos, Gabriela Judith C. Martines ella vende zapatos, Araceli O. S. J. ella vende comida, Mónica N. Z. ella vende cosméticos, Martha N. Z. ella vende zapatos, Francisca Z. P. ella vende pollo, Cecilia C. S. ella vende abarrotes y ropa, Yuslin Rodríguez Alarcón ella vende cosméticos.
texts.en:
Las Jarochas is a united group of hard-working women. This group is located in the Emiliano Zapata neighborhood of the city of Tierra Blanca, VeraC.. Cecilia C. S. is the group’s representative. She is 41, and the single mother of three children. She has two girls and a boy. She sells groceries and clothes. She needs the loan to stock her store. Cecilia says that her dream is to expand her store. That way one day she will convert it into a mini supermarket. She feels that because she lives so far from the center of the city, her business will prosper more because people will prefer to buy in her store. The members are: Cristela Rodríguez C. sells shoes, Yaret Q. N. sells purses and clothes, Petra Cochyuchi V. will start selling sweets and soft drinks, Gabriela Judith C. Martines sells shoes, Araceli O. S. J. sells food, Mónica N. Z. sells cosmetics, Martha N. Z. sells shoes, Francisca Z. P. sells chicken, Cecilia C. S. sells groceries and clothes, Yuslin Rodríguez Alarcón sells cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock the store

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Madame Aminata N. est une yoffoise de 38 ans qui habite à Yoff Mbenguene. Elle est membre de caisse depuis octobre 2002 et a déjà solde 4 prêts antérieurs. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1 an 2mois et 13 ans. Elle s’active dans le commerce de petit déjeuner et de produits divers depuis dix ans.  C’est une activité qu’elle a opte par passion mais aussi pour   éviter  d’être inactive et dépendante. Son objectif est de satisfaire sa clientèle et réaliser le maximum de bénéfices possible. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs pour l’achat des produits qui lui servent de matière premières qui peuvent être stockes. L’amélioration de ses revenus lui permettra de supporter les frais de scolarité de ses enfants qui sont dans le prive.
texts.en:
Ms. Aminata N. is a 38-year-old woman from Yoff, who lives in Yoff Mbenguene. She has been a member of the credit union since October 2002, and has already settled 4 previous loans. She is married and has 5 children, whose ages vary from 1 year and 2 months to 13 years. She has engaged in the business of selling breakfast meals and food items for ten years. This is a business she chose not only based on her passion, but also to avoid being inactive and dependent. Her goal is to satisfy her customers and realize the maximum profit possible. She is seeking a loan of 150,000 FCFA to buy goods that will serve as raw materials to be stocked. The improvement in her income will allow her to provide for her children's private school education.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Severo

texts.es:
Severo Q. R., tiene la edad de 64 años, está casado, y vive con su esposa y una nieta de 9 años ellas son su mayor prioridad. El crédito lo quiere para asistir su finca, específicamente para el cultivo de café, la idea es comprar el abono y el fertilizante. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo de café para lograr una mejor calidad y para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Severo también trabaja desde hace muchos años en la agricultura. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Severo Quiros R. is 64 years old, married, and lives with his wife and a 9-year-old granddaughter, who are his top priority. He is requesting a loan to help with his farm, specifically for the coffee crop. He wishes to buy manure and fertilizer. He would like to provide the right kind of attention to his coffee crop, for better quality and the best financial yield at harvest time. This is his first request for credit from FUDECOSUR, and he is very pleased with the possibilities made available to him. Severo has been farming for many years. In the future, he hopes to provide his family a better life and greater financial stability, as well as continue to grow as a person and producer. About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Help with coffee crop

loans.name: Ignacio

texts.en: Ignacio is thirty years old and married to Carmen Alvarez, who is thirty-four and sells empanadas to neighbors, friends, and Ignacio's clients. The couple has one child together who is beginning elementary school. Ignacio is a mechanic, and he has an established client base. He learned the profession from his cousin, who he worked with for more than ten years. Eight years ago, Ignacio opened his own shop, which has been very successful due to his good service and excellent work. He is seeking the loan to refurbish his house.

loans.use: To refurbish his house

loans.name: Alexis Clemente

texts.es: El Sr. Alexis Clemente Solís Sánchez, soltero, de oficio jardinero, su especialidad es la poda de árboles ornamentales, su crédito lo solicito para hacer mejoras en su vivienda, con la institución es su tercer crédito y dice sentirse satisfecho con las oportunidades que le brinda CEPRODEL de pagar sus  abonos de acuerdo a sus fechas de pagos, además que le ofrece cuotas acorde con su salario.
texts.en:
Alexis Clemente Solís Sánchez is single. He's a gardener and his specialty is ornamental tree trimming. He is asking for funding to make some home improvements. This is his 3rd loan with the institution and he says that he is content with the opportunities that CEPRODEL offers to repay his loan in addition to the fact that repayment amounts are based on his salary.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Mujeres Comprometidas Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inició la Señora Librada E. del Barrio Buena Vista de  _C.D.E. Ella Contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en su comunidad.
El comité se Denomina “Mujeres Comprometidas “ están en el Quinto Ciclo   con 15  integrantes , es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas, solidA.  y responsable entre ellas , las mismas realizan labores comunitA. y actividades para el comité,  poseen un ahorro de gs 5.253.868 gs.
